Idiom (Mirandese): Estar a dar burras nu naranjal
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive verb phrase with prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To waste time or effort on something pointless or absurd
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Fazer algo inútil ou sem sentido
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Humorous rural imagery from Douro region
First Example Sentence: Andeis a dar burras nu naranjal con isse problema que nun tien solução.
Second Example Sentence: Qu’esti home, semper a dar burras nu naranjal!
Third Example Sentence: L burro parez qu’está a dar burras nu naranjal cuando tenta usar l computador.

Idiom (Mirandese): Tenir l cazu al foc y l fumo al céu
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive phrase with coordinated noun phrases
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be overly ambitious or distracted by grand plans
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Tentar fazer demais ao mesmo tempo
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agrarian wisdom about tending cooking fires
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Mirandese): [teˈniɾ l ˈka.zu al ˈfɔk i l ˈfu.mu al ˈsɛw]
First Example Sentence: Nun pues tenir l cazu al foc y l fumo al céu si queres rematar ben.
Second Example Sentence: Sempre quere más, ya tien l cazu al foc y l fumo al céu.
Third Example Sentence: Tais assi cumo tenir l cazu al foc y l fumo al céu — acalma-te un pouco.

Idiom (Mirandese): Puxar l burro por la cola
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive verb phrase with prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To approach a problem in the wrong way
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rural farming imagery, Mirandese folk logic
First Example Sentence: Tás a puxar l burro por la cola cun esti projeto!
Second Example Sentence: Nun sirbe puxar l burro por la cola — pensa primero.
Third Example Sentence: Si puxas l burro por la cola, l burro nun vai endavant.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Desperdiçar algo bom com quem nun merece

Second Example Sentence: Esti regalo foi dar milho a porcos — nun valoran nada.
Third Example Sentence: A falar verdade, dar milho a porcos ya me cansa.

Idiom (Mirandese): Dar pan a quem ten fame
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive phrase with dative object and relative clause
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To do the right thing by helping those in need
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Christian charity tradition in rural Mirandese communities

Second Example Sentence: Dar pan a quem ten fame fai de ti un bon cristianu.
Third Example Sentence: La vieya foi dar pan a quem ten fame y toda la aldeia l’agradeceu.

Idiom (Mirandese): Meter os pes nu mesmo sapato

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To force different people or ideas into the same mold

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Critique of forced conformity under centralization

Second Example Sentence: Intentan meter os pes nu mesmo sapato con la educación.
Third Example Sentence: Meter os pes nu mesmo sapato ye cosa de burros.
